trial_identification.studytitle: Nurse-led chronic disease care in Wheatbelt, Western Australia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: To investigate whether an intensive practice nurse led chronic heart and lung disease primary care in Wheatbelt general practices will reduce avoidable hospitalisations as compared to routine general practice care.

interventions.interventions: Participants will be followed up three-monthly over a year. An individualised care plan will be formulated by the practice nurse with the participant in the initial consult (1 hour). This care plan will be reviewed every 3 months (0.5 hour each time). The care plan includes list of medication/s, list of medical condition/ medical history, dietary and lifestyle advice, what to do in medical emergency e.g. acute asthma attack.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Number of avoidable hospitalisation for asthma, COPD and hypertension in test and control sites during the intervention period using regional hospital morbidity and mortality dataset

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of Life as assessed by the SF-12 questionnaire

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: able to give informed consent; have a heart and/or lung chronic disease currently managed in primary care
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unable to give informed consent; chronic condition not well controlled or need intensive treatment; deemed not suitable for participation by treating clinicians; participants want to withdraw from the study

trial_design.concealment: Information sheets for the study are made available at the reception area of each participating general practice. Willing participants send signed consent form to researchers. Participants are screened by nurse whether they fully understand the purpose and scope of the intervention. An individualised care plan is formulated with the respective participant.
trial_design.designfeatures: Mixed methods: embedded QUAN(qual) with focus group conducted with willing informants (not necessarily participants of the study)
